title: Claws of Terrestrial Crustaceans: Structure, Composition and Mechanics
content: Crustacean skeletons are composite biological structural materials consisting of chitin-protein fibers embedded in a mineralized matrix. In most crustaceans, the dominant mineral in the exoskeleton is calcium carbonate, but calcium phosphate may also be present [1]. Skeletal elements capable of withstanding large forces are of particular interest, as they have the potential to inspire biomimetic materials and their designs [2].
